{
  "article_text": [
    "the influence of environmental degrees of freedom ( dof ) on quantum phenomena , like e.g. tunneling , has been of great interest during the last decades @xcite .",
    "a significant progress came from the investigation of a more or less phenomenological model where a particle in a one - dimensional potential @xmath5 or a free particle is coupled to a bath of harmonic oscillators with the spectral density @xmath6 .",
    "the quantum dissipation generated by the bath depends qualitatively on the low frequency behavior of @xmath6 @xcite .",
    "a particular interesting case is ohmic damping , when @xmath7 for low enough frequencies . in that case and for a symmetric",
    "double well potential , the particle at zero temperature undergoes a transition from a delocalized state to a localized one if the coupling constant between the particle and bath exceeds a critical value @xcite .",
    "an interesting observation has been made by caldeira and leggett @xcite .",
    "the exponent of the exponential factor for the tunneling probability is multiplied by @xmath8 , the phenomenological friction coefficient of the corresponding _ classical _ dynamics .",
    "this relationship between classical and quantum dissipation has been deepened and generalized by leggett @xcite for an arbitrary linear coupling between the particle and bath coordinates .",
    "let @xmath9 be the fourier transform of the classical particle trajectory @xmath10 and @xmath11 the transformed classical equation of motion , where @xmath12 contains the dissipative influence of the bath .",
    "then the reduced euclidean particle propagator @xmath13 ( where the harmonic dof have been eliminated ) can be represented by a path integral in the imaginary time @xmath14 @xcite @xmath15e^{-\\frac{1}{\\hbar } s[q(\\tau ) ] } \\label{eq2}\\qquad.\\ ] ] the action @xmath16 = s_0[q(\\tau ) ] + s_{nonlocal}[q(\\tau)]\\tag{3a}\\label{eq3a}\\ ] ] contains the local @xmath17 = \\int\\limits_0^td\\tau\\ , \\left[\\frac{m_p}{2}\\dot{q}(\\tau)^2+v(q(\\tau ) ) + \\frac{\\mu}{2}q(\\tau)^2\\right ] \\tag{3b } \\label{eq3b}\\ ] ] and the nonlocal part @xmath18 = - \\int\\limits_0^t \\,d\\tau\\int\\limits_0^{\\tau}\\,d\\tau'\\ , k(\\tau-\\tau')q(\\tau)q(\\tau ' ) = -\\frac{1}{2\\pi}\\frac{1}{2}\\int d\\omega \\,\\widetilde{k}(\\omega)| \\tilde{q}(\\omega)|^2 .",
    "\\tag{3c}\\label{eq3c}\\ ] ] the second equality holds for @xmath19 .",
    "@xmath20 is the fourier transform of the integral kernel @xmath21 and it is related to @xmath12 by @xmath22 .",
    "if the euclidean lagrangian of the particle - bath system is @xmath23 with @xmath24 and @xmath25\\tag{4c } \\label{eq4c}\\ ] ] then@xcite @xmath26 and @xmath27 with the spectral density @xmath28 for a finite @xmath2 the kernel @xmath21 and the paths @xmath29 can be periodically continued .",
    "then the fourier series for @xmath21 is given by the fourier coefficients @xcite @xmath30 with @xmath31 . here",
    "@xmath32 and @xmath33 are the masses of the particle and harmonic oscillators , respectively .",
    "@xmath34 are the oscillator frequencies and @xmath35 are the coupling constants between q and the coordinates of the oscillators @xmath36 .",
    "note that @xmath36 are not necessarily positions , but can represent normal mode coordinates of vibrations , etc .    in the following",
    "we will restrict ourselves to a system of @xmath37 particles whose potential energy @xmath38 includes harmonic and anharmonic interactions . without an external field , @xmath39 must be translationally invariant",
    ". however , since the coordinates of langrangian ( 4 ) are not specified , it is not necessarily invariant under translations .",
    "this has motivated chudnovsky @xcite to apply the caldeira - leggett approach to a system of two particles ( @xmath40 ) with positions @xmath41 and masses @xmath42 , coupled to oscillators with coordinates @xmath43 , frequencies @xmath44 and masses @xmath45 .",
    "the corresponding euclidean lagrangian is of the form @xmath46 \\label{eq6}\\ ] ] with @xmath47 being the interaction energy between both particles .",
    "the coupling of particle @xmath48 to the oscillators is assumed to be zero .",
    "it is obvious that @xmath49 is translationally invariant under @xmath50 provided that @xmath51 are real space coordinates .",
    "surprisingly the elimination of harmonic dof does not lead for zero temperature to a nonlocal action of caldeira - leggett type ( cf .",
    "( [ eq3c ] ) , ( [ eq5b]),([eq``1 '' ] ) ) .",
    "the fourier coefficients of chudnovsky s kernel have the form @xmath52 which differs qualitatively from the caldeira - leggett type result ( [ eq``1 '' ] ) .",
    "however , for @xmath53 one gets @xmath54 where the last term , up to the additional factor @xmath55 , corresponds to the second order time derivative of the kernel , identical to @xmath56 from eq .",
    "( [ eq``1 '' ] ) , if one chooses @xmath57@xcite .",
    "then the question arises : does a translationally invariant model in general lead to a nonlocal action , which is not of caldeira - leggett type ?",
    "this is one of the main points we want to investigate among others in our paper .",
    "it will be done for a microscopic(within a born - oppenheimer approximation ) , explicitly translationally invariant lattice model with a defect which can not diffuse .",
    "we will show how the normal mode coordinates for the harmonic dof can exactly be separated from the anharmonic ones .",
    "this leads to a lagrangian of the form of eq .",
    "( 4 ) with coupling constants @xmath58 , frequencies @xmath59 and a spectral density determined by the microscopic model parameters .",
    "such a microscopic justification of lagrangian ( 4 ) has been presented for quantum _ diffusion _ @xcite .",
    "there a particle diffusing through an elastic lattice is considered .",
    "if , however , that particle can not diffuse and is an integral part of the lattice , e.g. an impurity which can tunnel only between two positions , one has to separate the center of mass ( com ) and relative coordinates of _ all _ particles .",
    "for such a situation , sethna @xcite has estimated the coupling constants @xmath58 by comparing the strain field of an elastic monopole of an impurity with the displacement for a longitudinal mode .",
    "but , as far as we know , there is no microscopic derivation available for the quantities @xmath58 , @xmath59 and @xmath6 for a non - diffusing impurity in a lattice .",
    "besides such a microscopic derivation we will show that the quantum behavior of the defect is sensitive to its location .",
    "the outline of our paper is as follows : section [ model ] presents our model and outlines the main steps leading to lagrangian ( 4 ) .",
    "the implications for the quantum behavior will be discussed in the third section with a special emphasis on the role of defect location .",
    "a summary and conclusions are contained in the final section [ summary ] .",
    "appendices a , b and c contain details on the separation of the harmonic and anharmonic dof .",
    "we consider an open chain of @xmath37 particles with masses @xmath60 and harmonic nearest neighbor interactions and one anharmonic bond representing a defect .",
    "this model could describe a linear macromolecule with an impurity .",
    "the classical hamiltonian reads @xmath61 with the potential energy @xmath62 in which @xmath63 is the position of @xmath64-th particle , @xmath65 is the elastic constant of the harmonic nearest neighbor interaction , @xmath66 is the equilibrium length of the harmonic bonds and @xmath67 is the energy of the anharmonic bond defect located between the sites @xmath1 and @xmath68 .",
    "the potential energy @xmath39 is explicitly translationnally invariant .",
    "several ways exist to separate the harmonic and anharmonic dof , which finally lead to the langrangian ( 4 ) ( see appendices [ b ] and [ c ] )",
    ". one ( see appendix [ b ] ) , which is also applicable in higher dimensions , is to introduce the com @xmath69 and relative coordinates of the _ bond defect _",
    "@xmath70 then , @xmath71 are harmonic coordinates",
    ". their kinetic and potential energy can be diagonalized by introducing normal coordinates .",
    "@xmath72 is linearly coupled to these coordinates . as a result ,",
    "one obtains the lagrangian ( 4 ) . here",
    "we will choose a different approach applicable to 1d systems , which , however , leads to the same lagrangian .",
    "let @xmath73 be the com of _ all _ the particles and @xmath74 @xmath75 be the relative coordinates , respectively . using notation @xmath76 , eq .",
    "( [ eq12a]),([eq12b ] ) has the form @xmath77 with @xmath78 let @xmath79 be the canonical conjugate momenta of @xmath80 .",
    "it is easy to prove that eq .",
    "( [ eq13a ] ) implies @xmath81 substituting @xmath82 into eq .",
    "( [ eq13a ] ) yields @xmath83 here the first term is the kinetic energy of com , which will be dropped from now on .",
    "note that the use of relative coordinates introduces a coupling between the momenta . in the next step , we perform the canonical transformation @xmath84 @xmath85",
    "@xmath86 @xmath87 @xmath88 this leads to @xmath89 where @xmath90 is the defect hamiltonian , @xmath91 is the harmonic part of the hamiltonian and @xmath92 is the coupling between the two .",
    "the matrix @xmath93 in ( [ eq16c ] ) depends on the masses @xmath94 ( see appendix [ a ] ) .",
    "let @xmath95 and @xmath96 be the normalized eigenvectors and eigenvalues of * t * , respectively , and @xmath97 be the orthogonal matrix , which diagonalizes * t * , i.e. @xmath98 then we can introduce the normal coordinates @xmath99 for @xmath100 such that @xmath101 becomes diagonal @xmath102\\qquad .\\tag{19a}\\label{eq19a}\\ ] ] the interaction term takes the form @xmath103 the @xmath1 dependent coupling constants are given by @xmath104\\qquad .\\label{eq17}\\ ] ] the final step is the legendre transformation of @xmath105 , which leads to the euclidean lagrangian @xmath106 where @xmath107 and @xmath108 \\qquad .\\tag{21c}\\label{eq21c}\\ ] ] here we have used the equality @xmath109 ( cf .",
    "( [ eq15b ] ) ) and @xmath110 which follows from the completeness of the set @xmath111 of eigenvectors and @xmath112 ( see below ) .",
    "( [ eq19 ] ) allows us to include the counterterm @xmath113 in eq .",
    "( [ eq16b ] ) into @xmath114 .",
    "this counterterm , the role of which has been discussed by caldeira and leggett @xcite , results from the canonical transformation , eq .",
    "( [ eq15a ] ) , ( [ eq15b ] ) .",
    "this transformation eliminates the coupling between the momenta of the harmonic dof and that of the defect and generates coupling between the normal mode coordinates @xmath51 and the corresponding defect variable @xmath72 ( cf .",
    "( [ eq16d ] ) ) . due to the disappearance of the counterterm",
    ", there is no frequency renormalization for the bond defect@xcite .",
    "the lagrangian ( 21 ) is identical to that of eq .",
    "the masses @xmath115 and frequencies @xmath59 follow from @xmath116 and the reduced defect mass @xmath117 is given by @xmath118 note that these results are exact for one dimensional systems .",
    "it can be shown that for an _ arbitrary _ impurity in a two- or three - dimensional system the langrangian ( 21 ) can be derived within a kind of harmonic approximation @xcite .",
    "in this section we will investigate the zero temperature quantum behavior of the anharmonic bond defect embedded in the harmonic chain as shown in fig .",
    "[ fig ] .     particles .",
    "the masses @xmath119 , @xmath120 are chosen to be equal .",
    "@xmath66 is the equilibrium length of the harmonic bonds and @xmath121 the two degenerate equilibrium lengths of the anharmonic bond . ]",
    "we will assume that @xmath122 is a symmetric double - well potential with _ degenerate _ minima at @xmath123 and @xmath124 .",
    "then the classical ground state of @xmath125 ( cf .",
    ".  [ eq10b ] ) is twofold degenerate ( see fig.1 ) .",
    "therefore the low - lying eigenstates form doublets . neglecting the excited doublets at zero temperature",
    "is justified if the bare tunneling splitting of the ground state doublet is much less than the frequency of the upper phonon band edge @xmath126 ( see eq .",
    "( [ eq25a]))@xcite .",
    "if the total number @xmath37 of particles in the chain is macroscopically large and the particle number @xmath1 is in the bulk of the chain , i.e. @xmath127 , one might have expected a suppression of tunneling since the change from , e.g. @xmath128 to @xmath129 , would require a translation of the macroscopic mass of the left and right harmonic parts of the chain .",
    "we will see that this naive expectation is not always correct .    on the other hand , if the defect is close to one of the free boundaries , i.e. either @xmath130 or @xmath131 , only a finite mass @xmath132 has to be translated .",
    "consequently tunneling can not be suppressed .",
    "this qualitative @xmath1-dependence should follow from that of the kernel @xmath21 , which itself results from the strong @xmath1-sensitivity of the spectral density @xmath6 .",
    "subsection [ subsec_a ] discusses this phenomenon .",
    "the limit @xmath133 ( or @xmath134 ) , motivated by the conclusions drawn in ref .  @xcite , will be discussed in subsection [ subsec_b ] .      as we will see in subsection [ subsec_b ] the form of the nonlocal action eq .",
    "( [ eq3c ] ) does not depend qualitatively on the masses @xmath119 , even if one of the defect masses @xmath135 or @xmath136 becomes infinitely large",
    ". therefore we will choose for convenience @xmath137 .",
    "let us start with the situation where the bond defect is located within the bulk , i.e. @xmath127 , so that @xmath138 one can prove that the tunneling phenomena do not depend on @xmath139 if it is different from 0 and 1 .",
    "therefore we choose @xmath140 and without loss of generality @xmath37 to be even .",
    "this choice and the assumption @xmath137 allows us to determine the eigenfrequencies @xmath59 and the eigenvectors @xmath141 exactly for finite @xmath37 . a calculation , whose technical details are presented in appendix [ a ] , results in @xmath142 @xmath143 @xmath144 where @xmath145 for @xmath146 .",
    "it is easy to see that @xmath147 are the symmetric eigenvalues with respect to @xmath148 and @xmath149 are the antisymmetric ones . from this , @xmath150 and eq .  ( [ eq17 ] )",
    "it is obvious that the bond defect does not couple to the antisymmetric vibrational modes , as may be expected from the symmetry of the problem . with these results",
    "we can calculate the spectral density . making use of eqs .",

    "@xmath154 we obviously have @xmath155 which corresponds to the situation of ohmic damping .",
    "the ohmic damping results from two facts : first , the density of states @xmath156 of the vibrational modes in a one - dimensional lattice is constant for @xmath154 and second the squared coupling constant involves the factor @xmath157 which , for @xmath158 , @xmath159 with @xmath160 , oscillates faster and faster so that it can be replaced by 1/2 .",
    "it is emphasized that the condition @xmath161 , i.e. @xmath162 or 1 , will change the shape of @xmath6 qualitatively .",

    "is broken .",

    "the first integral yields a constant in the leading order in @xmath214 . for the second one we are allowed to replace @xmath215 by @xmath216 since the main contribution comes from @xmath217 so that the function @xmath200 is oscillating fast between zero and one , whereas @xmath218 varies slowly .",
    "accordingly @xmath219 corresponds to an effective spectral density @xmath220 , i.e. to ohmic damping .",
    "it is straightforward to estimate both integrals . as the final result",
    "we obtain @xmath221\\label{eq31}\\ ] ] + for @xmath222 . taking the limit @xmath223 in eq .",
    "( [ eq31 ] ) restores the result ( [ eq24 ] ) for the kernel @xmath21 .    for @xmath130 or @xmath224 , and @xmath174 we obtain for @xmath195 a crossover at @xmath188 from the power law   @xmath207 for @xmath219 to @xmath225 for @xmath226 .",
    "figure 2 illustrates this behavior for @xmath195 , calculated numerically . on the log - log plot of figure 2 the crossover between both power laws",
    "can easily be observed .",
    "this crossover is related to the @xmath1-dependence of the spectral density because the defect - phonon coupling constants @xmath227 are @xmath1-dependent .",
    "if the observation time @xmath2 ( which is the time @xmath2 in @xmath228 from eq . ( [ eq2 ] ) ) is smaller than @xmath188 then @xmath229 will be smaller than @xmath188 , as well .",
    "consequently the kernel @xmath230 entering the nonlocal action ( eq .",
    "( [ eq3c ] ) ) decays as @xmath231 . if , however , @xmath2 is larger than @xmath188 then it is possible that @xmath229 becomes larger than @xmath188 , as well . for those values of @xmath229",
    "the kernel @xmath232 decays as @xmath233 .",
    "this discussion reveals that the choice of the observation time @xmath2 allows to fix the large-@xmath194 behavior of @xmath195 , where , of course , @xmath234 . if @xmath1 is far away from the chain end the crossover time @xmath188 is correspondingly large .",
    "increasing @xmath1 even more @xmath188 increases , too .",
    "nevertheless , the observation time dependence still exists .",
    "it disappears for @xmath235 , only .",
    "we remind the reader that the limit @xmath174 has to be taken first .    now making use of the analogy @xcite between the calculation of the action of a multi - instanton configuration interacting via @xmath236 and a one - dimensional ising model with the coupling constants @xmath237 we can conclude the following :",
    "if the observation time @xmath2 is smaller than @xmath238 then we have @xmath239 , i.e. _ ohmic _ damping . in that case",
    "the bond defect may tunnel for @xmath240 , whereas symmetry becomes broken for @xmath241 .",
    "note , that this is not a sharp transition at @xmath242 since finite @xmath2 corresponds to a finite ising chain which does not exhibit a sharp phase transition .",
    "what really happens when increasing the coupling constant @xmath65 is an increase of the correlation length @xmath243 .",
    "as soon as @xmath243 equals the size @xmath2 of the ising - chain a long range order occurs .",
    "however , if @xmath2 is much larger than @xmath244 we have @xmath245 and tunneling is never suppressed @xcite .    one might be puzzled by these conclusions since the transition for ohmic damping to decoherence for @xmath246 occurs for large @xmath2 , or to be more precise it becomes a sharp transition for @xmath247 , only . as we already stressed above , the transition for @xmath248 is _ not _ sharp .",
    "the relevant phonons contributing to @xmath195 have wavenumbers @xmath249 .",
    "this makes the effective spectral density ohmic .",
    "mapping the situation for @xmath250 again onto the ising chain of length @xmath49 results in the coupling constants @xmath251 decaying like @xmath252 for @xmath253 and like @xmath254 for @xmath255 .",
    "it is clear that there is _ no _ sharp phase transition for finite @xmath49 .",
    "but if @xmath256 , the coupling constants decay as @xmath257 . for a fixed temperature @xmath2 ( not to be confused with the observation time @xmath2 ) there will be no magnetic order ( @xmath258 coherent tunneling ) for @xmath259 . for @xmath260 a crossover to the long range",
    "order ( @xmath258 decoherent tunneling ) takes place . accordingly the quantum tunneling phenomenon is richer for @xmath250 than for @xmath261 .",
    "actually we may think also in the real time @xmath262 terms that as long as only the phonons with relatively high frequencies @xmath263 and hence short wave length such that @xmath264 participate in the interaction with the anharmonic defect , the latter does not feel that the chain is finite and behaves as in the ohmic case . in the course of time the lower frequency phonons with higher wave length reach the end of the chain and a crossover to a superohmic behavior takes place .      in this subsection we will assume that @xmath265 for @xmath127 we may choose without loss of generality @xmath266 and @xmath37 being even .",
    "it is easy to prove that @xmath267 from eq .",
    "( [ eq25b ] ) remain eigenvectors of * t * with @xmath268 , @xmath269 given by eq .",
    "( [ eq25c ] ) .",
    "the remaining @xmath270 eigenvectors are of the form @xmath271 @xmath272 is a solution of transcendental equation . let us introduce the quantities @xmath273 , @xmath40 and @xmath274 .",
    "the limit @xmath275 ( or @xmath276 implies @xmath277 . since the results in @xcite motivate us to study , e.g. @xmath278 , we find @xmath279 in the limit @xmath280 .",
    "substituting eqs .",
    "( [ eq36a ] ) , ( [ eq36b ] ) into eq .",
    "( [ eq17 ] ) yields @xmath281 in the leading order in @xmath282 . as a result @xmath6 and therefore @xmath21 ,",
    "too , are doubled as compared to the case of @xmath283 , i.e. we get @xmath284 for @xmath285 .",
    "the only essential result of changing @xmath286 from @xmath287 to infinity is that the critical elastic constant increases by a factor of two .",
    "for a translationally invariant chain with one anharmonic bond and otherwise harmonic nearest neighbor interactions , we have shown exactly how the anharmonic degree of freedom can be separated from the harmonic ones in their normal mode representation . as a result , we have obtained lagrangian ( 21 ) , which is of the form of lagrangian ( 4 ) .",
    "note , that this result can also be obtained for a three - dimensional system within the born - oppenheimer approximation starting with an arbitrary translationally invariant potential @xmath288 for a @xmath37-particle system @xcite .",
    "since the caldeira - leggett type nonlocal action @xcite is based on the form ( 4 ) ( or ( 21 ) ) of the lagrangian it is not the translation invariance and therefore not the conservation of momentum , which can lead to a different type of nonlocal action .",
    "the discrepancy between our results and those of ref .",
    "@xcite may have the following origin . since the harmonic part of lagrangian ( [ eq6 ] ) is diagonal in @xmath43 , the harmonic variables @xmath43 are",
    "already normal mode coordinates . in that case",
    "a translation of the full system only changes the goldstone mode amplitude , let us say @xmath289 , but leaves all the other normal mode coordinates unchanged , i.e. @xmath290 , @xmath291 for any translation . if @xmath292 and @xmath293 in eq .",
    "( [ eq6 ] ) are real space coordinates then the coupling term @xmath294 is not translationally invariant for @xmath295 .    our model has allowed us to calculate explicitly , e.g. for @xmath296 and @xmath297 the coupling constants @xmath58 , the eigenfrequencies @xmath59 and the spectral density @xmath6 .",
    "the @xmath298-dependence of @xmath299 is determined by the density of states @xmath156 and the coupling constants @xmath58 .",
    "although @xmath156 for @xmath300 is independent of the number @xmath1 , the frequency dependence of @xmath58 exhibits a sensitivity to the location @xmath1 , which makes the affect of the harmonic bath on quantum tunneling @xmath1 sensitive . as a consequence ,",
    "the damping is ohmic if the bond defect is within the bulk of the chain and superohmic if it is close to the boundaries . for the former case there is a transition from a delocalized state ( due to tunneling ) to a localized one",
    "if the elastic constant exceeds a critical value @xmath0 , whereas tunneling is never suppressed in the latter case , provided the observation time @xmath2 is large enough compared to @xmath188 which is roughly @xmath1 times the instanton kink width . for @xmath248 ( since the thermodynamic limit @xmath174 had already been performed , @xmath1 must be finite , but can be arbitrary large ) the dissipation is effectively ohmic leading to a similar behavior when the bond defect is within the bulk .    if @xmath127 ( e.g. @xmath297 ) and if one of the masses of the bond defect tends to infinity , no significant changes occur except for doubling of the critical constant @xmath0 .",
    "this is obvious since , e.g. @xmath301 , makes the part of the chain to the right of the defect inactive , i.e. the phonons to the right do not act as a reservoir for the bond defect . accordingly , only half of the harmonic chain is generating dissipation , which results in doubling of @xmath0 .",
    "although we are not aware of a concrete experimental system , these results could be relevant for linear macromolecules , which may be described by the model hamiltonian eq .",
    "( 10 ) . if many of such molecules with a single defect are produced .",
    "the position of which can be controlled experimentally , one might observe , e.g. the location - dependent tunneling by spectroscopic methods .",
    "this work has been completed when two of us ( v.f . and r.s .",
    ") were a member of the advanced study group 2007 at the mpipks dresden .",
    "v.f . and r.s .",
    "gratefully acknowledge the mpipks for its hospitality and financial support",
    ". v.f . acknowledges a support of israeli science foundation , grant n 944/05 .",
    "one of us ( r.s . ) thanks eugene chudnovsky for helpful discussions .",
    "the separation of the harmonic and anharmonic dof by using the center of mass and relative coordinates of the _ total _ chain has been described in section [ model ] .",
    "the transformation to normal coordinates requires the diagonalization of the matrix * t*. here the most important steps of the diagonalization procedure are outlined .    making use of eqs .",
    "( 12)-(15 ) one obtains the matrix elements of the symmetric matrix * t * in the form @xmath302 @xmath303 and @xmath304 the diagonalization of * t * can not be done analytically for arbitrary masses @xmath94 .",
    "therefore we take the simplest case of equal masses , @xmath305 .",
    "then it is straightforward to prove that the eigenvalue equation @xmath306 is solved by @xmath307 @xmath308 where @xmath309 is the normalization constant and @xmath310 is a coefficient depending on the location @xmath1 of the bond defect .",
    "the wave numbers @xmath311 are solutions of the transcendental equation @xmath312 since the l.h.s . of eq .",
    "( [ eqa4 ] ) diverges at @xmath313 it is easy to see that its solutions are of the form @xmath314 with @xmath315 .",
    "there are @xmath316 solutions corresponding the @xmath316 harmonic dof .",
    "the remaining two dof are the com and the bond defect coordinate @xmath317 and @xmath72 , respectively . in the thermodynamic limit @xmath174 ,",
    "the discrete set of @xmath311 wave vectors becomes a continuous variable @xmath184 within @xmath318 $ ] with a constant density which together with eq .",
    "( [ eqa3 ] ) implies a constant low energy density of states .",
    "the normalization constant @xmath309 and the coefficient @xmath310 are functions of @xmath319 and @xmath37 .",
    "their explicit expressions are not given here .",
    "in this appendix we will describe the separation of harmonic and anharmonic dof using an approach alternative to that used in section [ model ] .",
    "it has the advantage that it can be straightforwardly applied to higher dimensional systems .",
    "the starting point is the introduction of com and relative coordinate @xmath320 and @xmath72 , respectively , of the _ bond defect _ ( see eqs .",

    "again it is straightforward to prove that the eigenvalue equation @xmath362 for @xmath363 is solved by @xmath364 @xmath365 with @xmath366 being the normalization constant and @xmath367 a @xmath1-dependent coefficient .",
    "the remaining equations for @xmath348 with @xmath368 and @xmath369 yield a nontrivial solution if a corresponding determinant vanishes .",
    "this condition leads to the transcendental equation @xmath370 for the wave numbers @xmath371 .",
    "although eq .",
    "( [ eqb17 ] ) looks quite different from the transcendental equation ( [ eqa4 ] ) it can be shown by use of identities for trigonometric functions that ( [ eqb17 ] ) and ( [ eqa4 ] ) are equivalent , i.e. the set of solutions @xmath372 of eq .",
    "( [ eqb17 ] ) and @xmath373 of eq .",
    "( [ eqa4 ] ) are identical .",
    "we have already stressed that @xmath331 from eq .",

    "straightforward but tedious calculations show that the complete lagrangian corresponding to the classical hamiltonian eq .",
    "( b2 ) is identical to the lagrangian ( 21 ) .",
    "particularly , it can be proven that @xmath374 from eq .",
    "( [ eqb12 ] ) is identical to @xmath227 from eq .",
    "( [ eq17 ] ) .",
    "in this appendix we will show that separation of the harmonic and anharmonic dof can be done by taking the left and right harmonic parts separately . similarly to the approach used in section [ model ] our first step is to separate the com of the _ total _ chain from the relative coordinates .",
    "this leads to the hamiltonian from eq .",
    "( [ eq11 ] ) . neglecting the kinetic energy of com",
    "( [ eq11 ] ) can be rewritten as @xmath375 where @xmath376 @xmath377 @xmath378 @xmath379 and the nonzero matrix elements are @xmath380 with @xmath381 for @xmath382 and @xmath383 for @xmath384 .",
    "let @xmath385 and @xmath386 be the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of @xmath387 .",

    "this type of approach describes the chain as a bond defect coupled to _ two _ baths of harmonic oscillators , the left and right part of the chain . for the path",
    "integral formalism we need the lagrangian . from ( [ eqc1a ] ) ,",
    "( [ eqc1b ] ) , ( c3 ) and ( [ eqc4a ] ) we can determine the velocities @xmath394 and @xmath395 as function of the momenta .",
    "solving for the momenta as a function of the velocities is straightforward but tedious .",
    "we report the final result @xmath396\\tag{c5a}\\label{eqc5a}\\ ] ] @xmath397\\tag{c5b}\\label{eqc5b}\\ ] ] @xmath398\\tag{c5c}\\label{eqc5c}\\ ] ] with @xmath399^{-1}.\\tag{c6}\\label{eqc6}\\ ] ] making use of ( c5 ) for the calculation of the legendre transform of @xmath105 from eq .",
    "( c1 ) leads to the euclidean lagrangian @xmath400 where @xmath401 in which @xmath402 + \\frac{1}{2 } \\sum_{\\mu=1}^{n - m-1 } \\left [ \\frac{1}{\\lambda_{\\mu}^r}(\\dot{x}_{\\mu}^r)^2 + c(x_{\\mu}^r)^2\\right],\\ ] ] @xmath403 ^ 2 , \\tag{c7c}\\label{eqc7c}\\ ] ] @xmath404.\\tag{c7d}\\label{eqc7d}\\ ] ] this form of @xmath49 differs completely from that of eq .",

    "( [ eq21a ] ) , ( [ eq21c ] ) .",
    "in addition , the harmonic part eq .",
    "( [ eqc7c ] ) is not diagonal ,",
    "i.e. due to the third term on the r.h.s . of eq .",
    "( [ eqc7c ] ) there is an intra- and an inter - coupling between the phonons ( normal modes ) of the left and right harmonic part of the chain .    in order to eliminate the harmonic degrees of freedom in the path integral representation of the propagator one has to diagonalize @xmath407 from eq .",
    "( [ eqc7c ] ) . this can be done by a point transformation @xmath408 and @xmath409 .",
    "this transformation follows directly from eqs .",
    "( [ eq15b ] ) , ( 18 ) and ( c2 ) : @xmath410 @xmath411 taking the time derivative of eq .",
    "( c8 ) yields the transformation of the velocities . substituting this and the transformation ( c8 ) into eq .",
    "( c7 ) diagonalizes @xmath407 and replaces the velocity coupling by a coupling of @xmath72 and @xmath51 . after a lengthy calculation one arrives at the lagrangian from eq .",
    "( 21 ) , which , of course , is not a surprise ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we investigate quantum tunneling in a translation invariant chain of particles . </S>",
    "<S> the particles interact harmonically with their nearest neighbors , except for one bond , which is anharmonic . </S>",
    "<S> it is described by a symmetric double well potential . in the first step , </S>",
    "<S> we show how the anharmonic coordinate can be separated from the normal modes . </S>",
    "<S> this yields a lagrangian which has been used to study quantum dissipation . </S>",
    "<S> elimination of the normal modes leads to a nonlocal action of caldeira - leggett type . </S>",
    "<S> if the anharmonic bond defect is in the bulk , one arrives at ohmic damping , i.e. there is a transition of a delocalized bond state to a localized one if the elastic constant exceeds a critical value @xmath0 . </S>",
    "<S> the latter depends on the masses of the bond defect . </S>",
    "<S> superohmic damping occurs if the bond defect is in the site @xmath1 at a finite distance from one of the chain ends . </S>",
    "<S> if the observation time @xmath2 is smaller than a characteristic time @xmath3 , depending on the location @xmath1 of the defect , the behavior is similar to the bulk situation . </S>",
    "<S> however , for @xmath4 tunneling is never suppressed . </S>"
  ]
}
